newsitem.title: USA: IMF wants to use existing resources on HIPC deal.
newsitem.headline: IMF wants to use existing resources on HIPC deal.

text.p: The International Monetary Fund hopes to use existing resources and bilateral contributions to fund its international debt relief plan for poor countries, but an official said gold sales could be an option later.

Jack Boorman, director of the International Monetary Fund's policy development and review department, told a news conference the IMF expected the Highly Indebted Poor Countries' (HIPC) initiative could cost it 2.5 billion Special Drawing Rights.
"There is agreement that after the efforts to secure as much as possible of this by bilateral efforts, consideration be given to the optimization of the fund's resources," he said.
He said this could mean selling five million ounces of IMF gold reserves, investing the proceeds and using the interest to fund the HIPC programme.
"The longer we wait to sell gold, the less interest income," he said, but added: "We have not yet reached the point where that decision has to be taken."

IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus has already suggested selling five million ounces of IMF gold to fund the HIPC program, but some member states have opposed the idea, fearing that gold sales could be inflationary.
The HIPC initiative aims to reward countries carrying out tough reform programs by providing them with debt relief.
